t: Ship*pn your grain across the sea; after*ld many days you may receive a return.
Invest*ln in seven ventures, yes, in eight; you*ld do not know what disaster may come upon the land.
If*pn clouds are full of water, they*ld pour rain on the earth. Whether*ln a tree falls to the south or to the north, in*ld the place where it falls, there it will lie.
Whoever*ln watches the wind will not plant; whoever*ld looks at the clouds will not reap.
As*pn you do not know the path of the wind, or*ld how the body is formed in a motherâ€™s womb, so*ln you cannot understand the work of God, the*ld Maker of all things.
Sow*pn your seed in the morning, and*ld at evening let your hands not be idle, for*ln you do not know which will succeed, whether*ld this or that, or*ld whether both will do equally well.
Light*pn is sweet, and*ld it pleases the eyes to see the sun.
However*ln many years anyone may live, let*ld them enjoy them all. But*ln let them remember the days of darkness, for*ld there will be many. Everything*ld to come is meaningless.

You*pn who are young, be happy while you are young, and*ld let your heart give you joy in the days of your youth. Follow*ln the ways of your heart and*ld whatever your eyes see, but*ln know that for all these things God*ld will bring you into judgment.
So*ln then, banish anxiety from your heart and*ld cast off the troubles of your body, for*ld youth and vigor are meaningless.
